title: MCP: list_mock_issues should derive priority from labels (schema-safe)
body:
Synopsis: Fix MCP mock-issue listing so 'priority' comes from labels, not a forbidden JSON field.

## Background
The MCP tool 'list_mock_issues' currently reads a top-level 'priority' key from each JSON file. Our Issue input schema does not allow arbitrary extra fields, so schema-valid mock issues cannot include 'priority'.

## Requirements
- Update MCP tool output so priority is inferred from labels (e.g., 'priority:high', 'priority:medium', 'priority:low').
- If no priority label is present, return 'unknown'.
- The tool must never crash if it encounters an unreadable/invalid JSON file; include it in results with a clear placeholder title.
- Update docs/examples to match the new behavior.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Schema-valid mock issues show priority based on labels.
- [ ] A mock file missing labels shows priority 'unknown'.
- [ ] Invalid JSON is handled gracefully (tool returns success; file is skipped or listed as unreadable, per existing pattern).
- [ ] Tests cover: priority from labels, unknown priority, invalid JSON handling.

## Where to look
- src/agent_mvp/mcp_server/server.py (list_mock_issues tool)
- src/agent_mvp/issue_sources/mock_issue_source.py (mock issue loading patterns)
- tests/test_mcp_server.py (existing MCP tests)
